Project Description  The Project covers six cities in Liaoning province and consists of 
the following: (i) coal bed methane (CBM) and coal mine methane 
(CMM) development and utilization  in Fuxin; (ii) gas distribution 
improvement in Benxi and Fushun; (iii) improvement of city central 
heating supply in  Anshan, Benxi, Liaoyang, and Yingkou; and 
(iv) institutional reforms and corporate governance improvement for 
all  project  implementing  agencies.  Policy  dialogue  with  the 
Government  during  project  processing  has  focused  on: 
(i) maximizing benefits to the poor and ensuring that the poor 
have sufficient heating by establishing specific gas and heating 
assistance programs, (ii) implementing market-based heating tariff 
reforms  and  improving  billing  collection  in  project  cities,  and 
(iii) promoting private sector participation.

atmosphere from coal mine operations. It is estimated that the 
coal mines in Liaoning released about 1.2 billion cubic meters (m3) 
of methane into the atmosphere in 2003, a figure expected to 
reach 2.0 billion m3 by 2010. Methane, when released into the 
atmosphere, is about 21 times more potent as a greenhouse gas 
than carbon dioxide (CO ). In addition, coal mine safety is a major

Risks and Assumptions  The risk of insufficient heating demand for the Project is minimal 
as the gas and central heating supply under the Project is mainly 
to  meet  existing  demand  and  a  small  fraction  of  incremental 
demand.  It  is  expected  that  macroeconomic  conditions  will

and  strong  economic  performance  in  Liaoning.  The  gas  and 
central  heating  supply  under  the  Project  is  based  on  proven

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the People's Republic of China (PRC) for the Liaoning Environmental Improvement Project. 
The project framework, which outlines the goal, purposes, outputs, activities, and inputs is 
presented in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
 
2.  The PRC has severe environmental problems, including air pollution associated with 
rapid economic growth,  heavy reliance on coal as the primary fuel, and  use of obsolete 
technology. The State Environmental Protection Administration (SEPA) estimated that since the 
early 1990s, pollution has resulted in a loss to the PRC economy of approximately 4% of gross 
domestic product (GDP). Air pollution accounts for 59% of this loss.1 Liaoning province is one of 
the provinces in the PRC with severe air pollution problems due to its heavy reliance on coal as 
the primary fuel for its many heavy industries and small coal-fired heating boilers. Before 2002, 
none  of  the  major  cities  in  Liaoning  met  the  national  air  quality  standards.  Due  to  the 
Government’s concerted effort on closing down small and highly polluting heating boilers, the 
urban air quality has been improved in recent years. In 2003, seven of 14 cities in Liaoning met 
the national air quality standards (Appendix 2). Supplementary Appendix A provides additional 
information. 
 
3.  Urban  heating  demand  has  grown  rapidly  due  to  rising  incomes,  privatization  of 
residential housing, and housing sector growth. As incomes increase, people living in the cold 
northern provinces have demanded more and better heating. Central heating in terms of square 
meters (m2) recorded an annual growth rate of 16.1% between 1992 and 2003. Nationwide, 
residential buildings account for about 70% of the total space heating, and commercial and 
public buildings account for the remaining 30%.  Heating demand in Liaoning has also been 
growing rapidly during the past decade. In the PRC, over 60 million tons (t) of coal are burned 
by 500,000 small, inefficient, coal-fired heating boilers every year, resulting in the emission of 
substantial amounts of sulfur dioxide (SO ), carbon dioxide (CO ), nitrogen oxides (NOx), and 
2 2
total suspended particulates (TSP). The majority of urban heating supplies in Liaoning come 
from 5,000 of these boilers, creating severe air pollution problems in urban areas. 
 
4.  The PRC is the world’s largest coal producer and consumer. Production of 1,667 million 
t of raw coal in 2003 accounted for about 33.5% of global production. Coal accounts for 95% of 
the nation's primary fossil energy resources and will continue to be the primary energy fuel for 
the foreseeable future. Coal production is expected to increase to 1,800 million t in 2004 due to 
the increased demand for power generation to meet  rapidly growing demand for  power. In 
Liaoning, coal production was 58 million t in 2003 with over 78 active coal mines with capacity 
greater than 30,000 t per year (t/y). State-owned coal mines account for 80% of coal production 
capacity. In the PRC, the coal bed methane (CBM)/coal mine methane (CMM) resources that 
could be produced from coal mines up to a depth of 2,000 meters are estimated at 30 to 
35 trillion cubic meters (m3).

B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
 
5.  The GDP of Liaoning grew 10.2% annually in real terms between 1990 and 1995, and 
8.5% between 1996 and 2003. One main development objective of the government of Liaoning 
province (GLP) is to contain the worsening trend of environmental pollution and ecosystem 
degradation, and to improve the environment in cities to demonstrate that rapid economic 
growth and a cleaner environment are compatible. GLP will strengthen its control of pollutant 
discharge by issuing regulations on total pollutant emission control and improving monitoring 
and enforcement. Air quality in cities will be improved through the substitution of coal by gas 
where feasible, closing of polluting small boilers for heating, and increased use of efficient 
technologies and management that minimize urban pollution. The operational strategy of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) in the PRC is aimed at helping the country achieve economic 
growth in an efficient, equitable, and sustainable manner. ADB’s energy sector strategy includes 
(i) developing  cleaner  energy  sources,  (ii) renovating  and  retrofitting  existing  facilities  to 
improve  efficiency  and  reduce  emissions,  (iii) promoting  the  corporatization  and 
commercialization of energy utilities, and (iv) pricing and tariff reforms. This is complemented 
by ADB's strategy for the environment sector that supports the use of economic, supply-side, 
and other measures to (i) ensure sustainable utilization of natural resources and promotion of 
market-based pricing and  (ii) encourage cost recovery and better environmental information 
disclosure. GLP will improve  air quality in   all major cities (including  all six project cities of 
Anshan,  Benxi,  Fushun,  Fuxin,  Liaoyang,  and  Yingkou)  to  meet  the  national  air  quality 
standards by 2010; the Project is a major part of the effort. By working toward  reducing 
emissions,  the  Project  is  consistent  with  and  provides  support  for  addressing  GLP’s 
development objectives. It is also consistent with ADB’s energy and environmental strategy 
(Appendix 3). 
 
6.  The PRC coal mines have high CBM/CMM content.2 Underground methane is a threat to 
the safety of coal miners because it is highly explosive. Methane must be removed during and 
sometimes prior to actual coal mining operations to ensure worker safety. Most of the methane 
removed in mining operations is not used as an energy source but emitted as a greenhouse gas 
into the environment. Coal mines in the PRC released approximately 6 billion m3 of methane 
into the atmosphere in 2003 and are expected to release approximately 10 billion m3 by 2010. 
As a  greenhouse gas, methane is approximately 21 times more potent  than carbon dioxide. 
Liaoning produces only 5.5% of the PRC’s coal, but accounts for approximately 20% of national 
methane emissions due to its geological conditions. Drainage of methane in underground coal 
mines has been undertaken in the PRC in an attempt to ensure safe production for decades. 
The removal of methane from underground coal mines does not always meet the required 
national standards, and has caused numerous fatal explosions. Under the Project, methane will 
be  commercially  extracted  as  an  economic  source  of  energy  that  will  be  distributed  to 
households and industries as a fuel. Efficient extraction and utilization of methane will  help 
reduce greenhouse gas emissions, improve the safety of coal mines, and reduce domestic use 
of coal. 
 
7.  Liaoning has a population of about 41 million, with 55% living in urban areas. As an old 
industrial base of the PRC, its economic structure is dominated by heavy industry with relatively 
old technology and large state-owned enterprises (SOEs).3 Because of its industrial structure

Continued strong economic growth, combined with  a significant increase in urban housing 
construction,  has  resulted  in  heating  demand  outpacing  supply.  Cities  in  Liaoning  are

mainly by SOE reforms and technology changes, and in particular, retrenchment of excess 
employees by large SOEs. The adverse effects of urban poverty are often compounded by 
environmental pollution from energy and heating sources at the household level. The poor do 
not have the information, access, or  funds for  more efficient (less-polluting) equipment and 
fuels. The gas and heating distribution systems are usually badly functioning or absent in the 
poorer sections of the city. Poorly maintained gas and heating distribution systems increase the 
exposure of the poor to daily doses of pollutants as well as to the risk of accidents. Indoor air 
pollution particularly puts women and children at risk. By improving the efficiency and capacity 
of city gas and heating distribution, closing  the existing  412 small heating boilers in Benxi, 
Liaoyang  and  Yingkou  cities,  and  implementing  tariff  reforms  and  special  tariff  reduction 
programs, the Project will help reduce environmental pollution and ensure that the poor have an 
affordable and sufficient heating supply. 
 
8.  The affordability of the poor for heating services is a major concern in Liaoning. The 
average heating bill for a poor household living in a 40 m2 apartment unit is about CNY167 per 
month during the 5-month long heating season. In a typical poor household of four people, the 
income at the poverty line is CNY780 per household per month in Anshan, CNY624 in Benxi 
and Yingkou, and CNY728 in Liaoyang.4 Thus, the heating bill represents a large portion of a 
poor household’s monthly income (21% in Anshan, 23% in Liaoyang, and 27% in Yingkou and 
Benxi). There is a serious affordability problem for poor households with income at or below the 
city poverty lines. In the project areas where the temperature in  the winter can go as low as 
minus 35o Celsius, insufficient heating supply will severely affect the quality of life and health of 
the poor. GLP is making efforts to provide urban minimum living standard and social assistance 
programs to address the growing concern of urban poverty. Cost savings resulting from the 
efficiency improvement of the Project will be passed on to the poor in the form of lower gas and 
heating  bill,  and  connection  fee  discounts.  These  programs  will  be designed to alleviate 
affordability problems and ensure sufficient heating for the poor in the project cities. 
 
9.  The resources of local governments and those provided by the central Government are 
inadequate to finance the large-scale investments required by rising gas and heating demand.5 
However, so far, the private sector has not been involved in gas distribution systems in the PRC 
and only a few joint ventures have been involved in combined heat and power generation plants 
and small CBM/CMM development operations. The present conditions in these subsectors do 
not provide enough incentives to make them attractive to private investors because (i) coal mine 
companies had poor financial performance before 2003 due to low coal prices; (ii) CBM/CMM 
development  is  still  in  its  infant  stage  with  perceived  commercial  risks;  (iii) there  are 
technical/institutional uncertainties involving city governments’ control over gas and heating 
distribution; (iv) heating has been considered as part of the welfare system, leading to poor fee 
collection; and (v) for gas and heating supply, clear and transparent tariff setting and approval

10.  The PRC has increased its coal production in the last 2 years to meet the fast-growing 
power generation requirements. Increasing coal production runs the risk of increasing the 
already high rate of coal mine accidents. The PRC has one of the worst records on mine 
fatalities. According to official figures, in 2002 about 6,900 miners died because of accidents, 
including  266 in  Liaoning.  However,  other  estimates  place  the  figure  above  10,000.6  The 
enforcement of mine safety and health laws at the local level is weak and ineffective. Small 
mine  operators  and  miners  do  not  follow  safety  and  health  best  practices.  The  Labor 
Department of the United States has provided two grants totaling $6.4 million to help worker 
protection and mine safety in the PRC (Appendix 3). Coal mine safety improvement is a priority 
for GLP. The Project provides a good opportunity to address the issue of coal mine safety and 
some safety programs will be incorporated into the project design to improve mine safety. 
 
11.  During  the  2002  Country  Programming  Mission,  the  Government  requested  project 
preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) from ADB to review and upgrade its feasibility study for 
the Project.7 However, GLP subsequently informed ADB about its concern over the local funding

C.  Special Features 
 
20.  Urban Heating Tariff Reforms. Heating tariff reforms are required to improve and to 
sustain urban heating supply. The current average heating tariff of about CNY20/m2 for the 
heating season in Liaoning is not low.10 Therefore, tariff reforms need to focus on the tariff 
structure and collection. At present, all of the urban heating tariffs are based on a simple fixed 
rate per square meter (e.g., CNY/m2) of the living area or construction area of buildings. The 
current heating tariff structure, payment, and collection systems have many problems including 
the following: (i) tariffs do not reflect the cost of providing heating services, (ii) the tariff structure 
does not encourage efficient use of heat, (iii) the enterprise-based tariff payment system is not 
market-oriented and causes difficulty in tariff collection, and (iv) a lack of transparent criteria and 
methodologies for tariff setting and adjustment. In addition, the layout of the piping system in 
existing buildings makes it difficult for the heating company to disconnect supply to delinquent 
customers. In Liaoning, heating bills are generally paid by employers for their employees. In the 
mid-1990s, many SOEs became financially unviable and could not pay the heating bills for their 
employees. This caused tariff collection to drop to 60%, creating severe financial difficulties for 
the heating companies. Tariff collection improved to 80–85% in 2003 and a further improvement 
to 95% is expected with the Project. 
 
21.  To address these issues, GLP will implement the agreed heating tariff reforms in the 
project cities (Supplementary Appendix E). The consultants under Part D will help remove the 
barriers  and develop specific reform action plans for: (i) installing lock valves in apartment units 
in buildings to help improve tariff collection efficiency, (ii) installing radiator control valves in 
apartment units to encourage heat conservation, (iii) implementing a two-part heating tariff so 
that the variable charge will be based on actual heat consumption, (iv) installing heat-measuring 
devices in apartment units to support consumption-based billing systems, and (v) training of 
heating company staff on implementation of reform measures. After the reforms, consumers will 
have the ability to regulate the amount of heat that they consume. This is essential for tariff-
based incentives for heat conservation, installing insulation, and taking measures to reduce heat 
loss to work. All new buildings in Liaoning are now required to follow new building codes and 
use energy-efficient building materials.

currently account for 21% to 27% of the average monthly incomes of poor households. Though

two specific programs. The first program will require the PIAs to provide gas and heating

committed to share the benefits and extend the discount to the poor after satisfying the loan

households),  resulting  in  an  annual  benefit  of  CNY20 million  in  connection  fees,  and 
CNY12 million in discounts on gas and heating bills. This will be about 4% of the total revenue 
of the gas and heating companies after the Project is complete. The second program requires

A.  Economic and Financial Viability 
 
1.  Least-Cost Assessment and Economic Viability 
 
46.  The PPTA consultants reviewed the demand forecast for the Project and concluded that 
the risk associated with the demand forecast is minimal (Supplementary Appendix N). This is 
because the Project will provide supply to meet only a fraction of the total gas and heating 
demand in the project cities. The gas distribution component will meet only a small share of the 
total incremental demand for gas in the project cities. The city central heating supply component 
will replace the existing small boilers to meet  existing heating demand. There is little risk 
associated with the demand forecast in the economic and financial viability analyses. A least-
cost analysis was performed for the two categories of end use to be served by the Project, 
including:  (i) household  cooking  and  water  heating  and  (ii) household  space  heating.  For 
household cooking and water heating, the analysis indicates that coal gas is the least-cost 
option. When CBM/CDM are available, they are the least-cost options. For household space 
heating, the least-cost analysis concludes that combined heat and power proposed for Yinkou 
city heating supply and large boilers proposed for other cities for heating supplies are the least-
cost options.  
 
47.  The  economic  internal  rate  of  return  (EIRR)  was  calculated  for  each  project 
subcomponent and for the whole Project including all project components. As in the least-cost 
analysis, the economic analysis applied the conversion factors to investment costs for land,17 
equipment  cost,  fuel  costs,  and  operation  and  maintenance  costs,  where  applicable.  The 
benefits of output were valued based on the cost saving of alternative fuels and efficiency 
improvement. The cost-saving benefits were valued as the cost differences of the energy supply 
options with and without the Project. A survey was carried out to determine the appropriate 
energy supply options for each category of consumers. The local environmental benefits were 
taken into account in the EIRR calculation. Line losses were based on the statistics of historical 
line-loss rates in each project city. 
 
48.  An economic evaluation of the environmental  impacts of the Project was carried out 
based on the benefits transfer method. The evaluation used (i) the methodology adopted in 
ADB’s Economic Evaluation of Environmental Impacts: A Workbook (1996) to determine the 
adjusted estimate of the monetary damages caused by air pollution during the study period, 
taking into account the location of the pollution sources, the emission level, and the population 
affected; and (ii) estimates of average annual climate change for carbon emissions to evaluate

C.  Social Benefits  
 
52.  The Project will directly benefit an urban population of about 2.7 million in the six project 
beneficiary cities.18 Among these people, 1.9 million urban residents will benefit from gas supply 
and 0.8 million urban residents from central heating supply. Of the total beneficiary population, 
about 199,800 people (7.4% of the beneficiaries) have incomes below the local urban poverty 
lines (ranging from CNY1,872 to CNY2,460 per year). The increased use of gas and better 
central heating supplies will reduce the use of conventional fuels such as raw coal, wood, and 
coal briquettes to mitigate environmental and health impacts, particularly on the poor. 
 
53.  The Project will create about 7,280 person-years of employment opportunities during the 
project construction phase and 1,940 full-time jobs during the operation of the Project. Of the 
total, 2,910 person-years of employment opportunities will be filled by the poor, women, and 
minorities  with  an  estimated  total  of  CNY28 million  in  wage  payments  during  the  project 
construction period. In addition, 780 employment opportunities with CNY8.4 million of annual 
wage payments are expected to go to the poor, women, and minorities during project operation. 
Local procurement of the materials required for the Project is expected to create additional jobs. 
The improved urban environment should enhance the local investment climate to attract more 
investment to the region and act as a catalyst for future development. 
 
54.  The improvement of  the air quality will reduce the morbidity and mortality rate of air-
related diseases and associated medical costs, loss of working days, as well as human suffering 
in the project beneficiary areas. The poor, elderly, children, and women, who have less coping 
resources and are more vulnerable, will benefit disproportionately from the replacement of coal 
and wood. In particular, women usually spend more time than men on cooking; the length of 
their exposure to smoke is considerable higher than men’s. Moreover, survey results show that 
the majority of  urban residents consider that  greater gas and central heating supplies will 
improve the overall quality of life, reduce  housework for women, decrease health problems, 
increase comfort and entertainment activities, and  encourage children to study longer in the 
winter. A benefit distribution and poverty impact ratio analysis was carried out to compute the 
poverty impact ratio of the Project (Appendix 13). The share of net project economic benefits 
directly  accruing  to  the  poor  is estimated at 13.9%.    Since  the  poverty  impact  ratio is 
substantially higher than the ratio of poverty population to total population in the project areas 
(7.4%), the Project is considered to be pro-poor.

however, involves some technical risks such as the use of vertical wells to extract CBM/CMM

is worth developing in the PRC as the potential benefits substantially outweigh the risks.

and procurement was addressed by early preparation and procurement training for all the PIAs

procurement. International and domestic consultants will also provide assistance in these areas 
In addition, all of the PIAs will be subject to good governance supervision under the PPMS. 
 
57.  To fully assess the potential project risks, a probabilistic risk analysis was performed 
using the Monte Carlo simulation technique based on 3,000 simulations for both the EIRR and 
FIRR analysis (Supplementary Appendix Q). The crucial risk variables were selected because 
of their significant impact on the project’s economic and financial viability. The results indicate 
that the expected EIRR, based on the weighted average of all simulated combinations, is 
25.3%, or about 1.0% lower than the base-case value, without consideration of project risks. 
The probability of the EIRR falling below the cut-off rate of 12% is 0.3%. The economic risk is 
very  low  because  the  Project  relies  on  existing  demand  and  benefits  from  efficiency 
improvements. The results indicate that the expected FIRR is 8.6%, about 0.1% lower than the 
base-case value, without consideration of project risks. The probability of the FIRR falling below 
the WACC for the Project of 4.3% is 16.9%. 
 
58.  Poverty is associated with vulnerability. The dimension of risk in poverty assessment is 
of significance since the poor are the most vulnerable to unexpected unfavorable events. The 
expected  poverty  impact  ratio  is  12.1%,  1.8%  lower  than  the  base-case  value,  without 
consideration of project  risks, and still higher than the share of the poor in the project area. 
Even with pessimistic assumptions, the probability of a negative outcome for the poor is 6.7%. 
The risk analysis on  the poverty impact ratio calculation, together with the analysis on the 
probability of overall project failure (risk analysis on the EIRRs and FIRRs), concludes that that 
the probability of negative outcomes for the poor is also minimal.

SECTOR AND SUBSECTOR ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Energy Sector and Environment 
 
1.  The People’s Republic of China (PRC) has severe environmental problems, including air 
pollution associated with rapid economic growth, heavy reliance on coal as the major fuel, use of 
obsolete equipment, and inappropriate planning associated with a centrally planned economy. 
Estimates of economic losses caused by pollution range from 3.5% to 8.3% of gross domestic 
product (GDP). Pollution in the early 1990s resulted in annual economic losses of CNY99 billion 
(about 4% of GDP at the time), with air pollution accounting for 59%, water pollution 36%, and 
solid waste 5%.1 The high economic losses reflect waste and inefficiency in the utilization of 
energy, raw materials, and other resources in the production of goods and services. This is partly 
a legacy of  the past practice of locating industrial enterprises in urban centers, inappropriate 
regulatory  measures,  and  pricing  policies  that  did  not  provide  adequate  incentives  for 
conservation and environmentally friendly behavior. With rapid economic growth, the use of 
energy and raw materials will continue to grow in the PRC. Unless better technologies are used, 
switching to cleaner fuels is encouraged, and the use of renewable energy is increased, air quality 
will deteriorate and related economic losses will increase. Supplementary Appendix A provides 
additional information. 
 
2.  The PRC's heavy reliance on coal as its primary fuel for industrial production, power 
generation, and commercial and residential applications, mainly heating and cooking, contributes 
significantly to emissions of sulfur dioxide (SO ) and total suspended particulates (TSP), and high 
2
levels of urban air pollution. Air quality is poor in most of the PRC’s industrial cities. Liaoning 
province has air pollution problems due to heavy reliance on coal as the primary fuel for the large 
number of heavy industries in the province and for heating. Most urban heating is provided by 
small, inefficient, coal-fired heating boilers. These small boilers typically are not equipped with 
adequate pollution control devices, and have been the major sources of air pollution in urban 
areas in the province. Shenyang and Benxi in Liaoning province are among the most polluted 
cities in the world. Due to the Government’s effort on environmental improvement, urban air 
quality has been slowly improving.  
 
B.  Coal Subsector 
 
3.  The PRC is the world’s largest coal producer with 2002 production of 1,393 million tons (t) 
of raw coal accounting for 28% of the world’s total coal production. Coal provides more than three 
quarters of the energy for power generation, 65% of chemical raw materials, and more than half of 
commercial and civilian energy. Coal accounts for 95% of the nation’s primary fossil energy 
resources. Coal will continue to be the primary energy fuel in the PRC for the foreseeable future, 
partly because of increasing thermal power capacity. Coal production reached 1,400 million t in 
1996 and then gradually energy efficiency was improved and other sources of energy were 
developed. Coal production was 1,000 million t in 2000 and increased to 1,667 million t in 2003. 
Coal production in Liaoning totaled 54 million t in 2000 and increased to 58 million t in 2003. 
Liaoning has over 1,300 active coal mines. State-owned coal mines account for 80% of coal 
production capacity.

C.  Gas Distribution 
 
4.  In the PRC, three types of gas are distributed: manufactured town gas,2 natural gas, and 
liquefied  petroleum  gas  (LPG).  Liaoning  province  has  4,470  kilometers  (km)  of  town  gas 
distribution  pipelines,  2,951  km  of  natural  gas  distribution  pipelines, and 195 km of LPG 
distribution pipelines. The most important end uses for city gas are cooking, water heating, and 
space heating to a lesser degree. In 2000, total city gas consumption in the PRC was 34 billion 
cubic meters (bcm), consisting of 15.2 bcm of coal gas, 8.2 bcm of natural gas, and 10.5 million t 
of liquefied petroleum gas (LPG). All the existing gas distribution systems are owned and 
operated by municipal gas companies under the control of city governments and under the 
supervision of the Ministry of Construction at the national level. The gas prices for end use 
consumers used to be subsidized before as a basic human need under the centrally planned 
system but have recently been adjusted nearer to market prices. The average gas price  in 
Liaoning, about CNY1.0/cubic meter (m3) (heat  value  of  5,000  kcal/m3), is comparable to 
CNY1.3/m3 (heat value of 8,000 kcal/m3) for many provinces in the PRC. Compared to coal, 
distribution of gas is more convenient and less polluting. The growing demand for city gas has 
been outpacing supply. Total city gas demand is expected to grow to 100 bcm by 2010, almost 
tripling during the 2000 to 2010 period. 
 
D.  Urban Heating 
 
5.  Urban heating demand in the PRC has grown rapidly due to rising incomes, privatization 
of housing, and housing sector growth. In terms of heated areas, heating demand has increased 
by an annual average rate of 17% from 1992 to 2003. Urban heating demand had grown rapidly 
during the past decade because of economic and housing growth and housing reforms that 
promoted private ownership. The total heated area of buildings in the PRC was only 328 million 
square meters (m2) in 1992 but more than quadrupled to 1,460 million m2 in 2002, equivalent to a 
compound annual growth rate of 16.1%. Residential buildings account for about 70% of the total 
space heating demand, and commercial and public buildings account for the remaining 30%. In 
2002,  30%  of  total  residential  buildings  were  served  by  combined  heat  and  power 
generation/urban central heating supply. This market penetration of central heating is relatively 
low, compared to the 55% to 60% range in developed European countries such as Denmark and 
Finland. About 500,000 small coal-fired heating boilers still operate in the PRC. As part of its 
energy efficiency and environmental improvement plan, the Government’s policy promotes urban 
central heating supply  systems using heat supplied from efficient, large, combined heat and 
power generation plants and/or large heating boilers. Similar to the national trend, the heating 
demand in Liaoning province has been growing rapidly in the past ten years. The total heated 
space in the province grew at 13.6% per year, increasing from 69.8 million m2 in 1992 to 
220.5 million m2 in 2001. In Liaoning, the average heating tariff of about CNY20/m2 is the same as 
or comparable to the CNY20/m2 in Heilongjiang, CNY19.5 /m2 in Xinjiang, and CNY24/m2 in 
Beiijing.

a greenhouse gas into the atmosphere that could otherwise be used as an energy source. In the

transmission and distribution (about 17%), and renewable energy (about 6%). ADB has also 
provided 67 technical assistance (TA) projects for the energy sector for about $32 million to help

B.  Lessons Learned 
 
5.  ADB’s overall experience from energy and environment sector projects in the PRC has 
been  positive.  Projects  are  generally  well  designed  and  smoothly  implemented,  although 
substantial  difficulties  have  emerged  in  some  projects.  Success  is  attributed  to  extensive 
preparation prior to ADB intervention, high degree of local ownership, effective leadership in 
project management offices (PMOs), timely policy and enterprise reforms, and fortunate market 
conditions. Delays in mobilizing counterpart funds are not uncommon, but in most cases have not 
resulted in unsatisfactory performance.  
 
6.  Some problems in energy projects have arisen from inappropriate policies on energy 
pricing, especially coal vs. natural gas (and urban heating), and enforcement of environmental 
protection requirements. For instance, the Shaanxi Environment Improvement Project (Loan 
1543-PRC), in general, has been successfully implemented, but experienced the cancellation of 
two cogeneration subprojects due to fuel pricing considerations, i.e., while natural gas was the 
environmentally favored alternative, extant gas pricing would have required subsidies of 30–50% 
to achieve a positive financial internal rate of return.  
 
7.  Persistent regulatory loopholes and weak enforcement of key provisions pose some 
project risk: emissions fees for SO  and other waste gas emissions are still set below the marginal 
2
cost  of  abatement,  making  it  cheaper  for  large  coal-fired power plants and synthetic gas 
producers to pay the pollution discharge fees than to implement de-sulfurization methods. Waste 
coal power plants are given some regulatory exemption from stack emissions standards, based 
on the “comprehensive reutilization” principle. Sustained enforcement of total emissions quotas 
on  a  provincial  and  air-shed basis was at least partially successful in the late 1990s, but 
construction and operation of large coal-fired power plants in the project area may jeopardize the 
long-range emissions control plan.  
 
8.  Ongoing market reforms in gas and heating subsectors pose uncertainties in financial 
viability  of  project  enterprises,  particularly  state-owned  enterprises  in  the  early  stages  of 
corporatization and commercialization. Ongoing environmental improvement projects (e.g., Loan 
1715-PRC and Loan 1890-PRC) illustrate that market reforms and material price volatility can 
outpace  project  implementation  with  two  extreme  outcomes:  (i) constraining  enterprise 
profitability,  or  (ii) enterprise  mergers  and  acquisitions  may  accelerate  management  and 
ownership reforms to the point that external support is not critical. A recent completed project 
performance audit report of a similar environmental project (Loan 1270: Tangshan and Chende 
Environmental Improvement Project) identified several important lessons including choosing 
suitable (not the most advanced) technology, integrated environmental and financial impacts, and 
emphasis on implementation.  
 
9.  The above lessons have been taken into account in project design and preparation. The 
Air Pollution Control Law (amended in 2000–2001) provides a rational regulatory framework 
promoting clean energy development in an environmentally friendly manner. Coal mine methane 
(CMM) has been demonstrated as a viable energy source in Liaoning province. The proposed gas 
and heating and coal bed methane (CBM) will be developed to meet existing demand and a 
fraction  of  the  total  incremental  demand  in  the  project  cities.  Price  forecasts  have  been 
conservatively estimated. The PMO has sufficient experience as it  has just completed  the 
implementation  of  a  loan  from  the  World  Bank.  Institutional  strengthening  of  the  project 
implementation  agencies  will  be  implemented  in  parallel  with  loan-funded  investments. 
Coordination with the World Bank and JBIC is active and ongoing, eliminating any overlap in 
assistance.

SUMMARY INITIAL ENVIRONMENTAL EXAMINATION 
 
A.  Introduction 
1.  This appendix summarizes the benefits, adverse effects, and recommended mitigation 
and monitoring measures related to the construction and operation of the Liaoning Environmental 
Improvement Project (the Project) in the People’s Republic of China (PRC).  It is based on 
environmental examinations and assessments prepared for individual subcomponents which 
include field sampling and assessment, interviews, and analysis of secondary data. 
 
B.  Project Description 
2.  The Project includes: (i) improved and expanded coal mine methane (CMM) and coal bed 
methane (CBM)1 production in Fuxin city, totaling 46 million cubic meters per year (m3/y); 
(ii) rehabilitation and expansion of gas transmission and distribution networks in Benxi and 
Fushun cities; and (iii) construction and operation of central heating systems in the cities of 
Anshan,  Benxi,  Liaoyang,  and  Yingkou  to  replace  small  coal-fired  heating  boilers;  and 
(iv) institutional reforms and corporate governance improvement of the project implementation 
agencies (PIAs). 
 
C.  Description of the Environment 
3.  Liaoning  province  is  located  on  the  northeast  coast  of  the  Asian  continent  at 
118o51'–125o47' E and 38o43'–43o29' N with a width of 374 kilometers (km) from east to west and 
530 km from south to north. The climate is continental monsoon, with mean annual precipitation 
from 1,200 millimeters (mm) to 400 mm, decreasing from the southeast to northwest. The average 
annual temperature is 10.1oC. Natural resources include coal, iron, limestone, and petroleum. 
Agricultural products include oil plants, fruits, rice, corn, apples, pears, peanuts, and other cash 
crops. Liaohe oil field is the third largest in the PRC, with crude oil and natural gas reserves that 
account for 15% and 10% of the total of the PRC, respectively. Despite having significant energy 
resources, the project area is a net energy importer. Conventional petroleum and natural gas 
reserves  are  declining,  and  coal  production  is  insufficient  to  meet  energy  demand  in  an 
environmentally acceptable manner. Liaoning is a traditional heavy industrial base of the PRC, 
with severe air, water, and soil pollution. Air pollution has been improving in the project area, but 
does not yet meet the designated ambient quality standards on a year-round basis. The ambient 
total suspended particulates (TSP) level exceeds PRC Grade II standards in all the project cities; 
ambient sulfur dioxide (SO ) concentrations frequently exceed Grade II standards.

Ongoing ecological improvements include: creation of approximately 5,800 hectares of green

abatement measures such as temporary barriers will be constructed as necessary to meet

11.  The Project will improve and expand clean energy supplies, improve energy efficiency, 
improve regional and indoor air quality, and reduce the explosion hazards associated with

POVERTY IMPACT RATIO ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Methodology 
 
1.  The poverty impacts of the Project are assessed by evaluating the expected distribution of 
net economic benefits among different groups. The approach takes only the direct project benefits 
into account in assessing poverty impact. The direct project benefits include: (i) lower gas and 
heating tariffs due to more efficient supply and (ii) environmental benefits. The methodology 
involves three steps. The first step is to estimate the present value of net financial and economic 
benefits by participating group. Next, group-wise, the financial benefits are deducted from the 
economic benefits to give the distribution of net economic benefits. Finally, the net economic 
benefits (NEB) accrue to the poor according to the proportion of each group that is poor. A poverty 
impact ratio expressing the proportion of NEB accruing to the poor can be calculated by 
comparing NEB to the poor with NEB of the Project as a whole.1 The analysis used constant 2003 
prices, a standard conversion factor of 0.93, and a discount rate of 12%. Tradable commodities 
were valued at border prices at the prevailing exchange rate. Nontradable commodities were 
valued at shadow prices, using a mix of standard and specific conversion factors. Net financial 
benefits (NFB) and NEB are expressed in yuan (CNY). 
 
B.  Benefit Distribution 
 
2.  The  NFB  are  equal  to  sales  revenue  of  CNY2,671 million  minus  capital  costs  of 
CNY740 million, operating costs of CNY1,744 million, labor costs of CNY246 million, and income 
taxes of CNY121 million. The NFB of the Project shows a loss of CNY181 million in net present 
value at 12% discount rate (Table A13.1). The NEB of the Project expressed at the domestic price 
level are CNY1,012 million. They are  equal to gross benefits of CNY3,887 million (including 
consumer surplus and environmental benefits) minus capital costs of CNY800 million, operating 
costs of CNY1,866 million, and labor costs of CNY208 million (wages valued at the shadow price 
of labor for both skilled and unskilled labor). 
 
3.  The difference between the NEB and the NFB is distributed by groups. The difference of 
CNY1,193 million is made up of (i) consumer surplus of CNY307 million (mainly in terms of the 
difference between the without-project cost of gas and heating supply and the with-project 
expenditure on gas and heating plus the value of gas and heating supply consumed but not paid 
for; (ii) the environmental benefits of CNY909 million from efficiency improvement, and closure of 
small, coal-fired boilers; (iii) the difference between financial and economic cost of capital 
investment and operating costs of CNY60 million and CNY122 million, respectively (mainly due to 
government taxes and duties, overvaluation of the exchange rate, and other price distortions); 
(iii) loss to skilled labor of CNY31 million (current wages less opportunity cost of labor); (iv) gain of 
unskilled labor of CNY68 million; and (v) income taxes of CNY121 million.  
 
4.  The differences between the NEB and the NFB give rise to losses and gains among the 
project participants. Considering the overall result of a NFB of negative CNY181 million and a 
NEB of CNY1,012 million for the Project, the NEB exceeds the NFB by CNY1,193 million. Skilled 
labor will lose by CNY31 million and the gain of unskilled labor by CNY68 million at the project 
wage levels that are lower (higher) than the opportunity costs, while the consumers will gain from 
their consumer surplus of CNY307 million. The investor (project companies) of the Project will 
loss CNY181 million at a discount rate of 12%. Since project companies are state-owned 
enterprises, the CNY181 million losses could be considered as the Government's financial loss

C.  Poverty Impact Ratio 
 
5.  The differences between the financial and economic values, and the consequent gains 
and losses for different project participants, provide the basis for considering the impact of the 
Project for the poor. The poor account for 7.4% of the people living in the project area.2 The 
incremental  gas  and  better  heating  supply  could  benefit  the  urban  poor  more  as  their 
consumption are projected to increase faster because of their current low consumption levels. 
The government of Liaoning province agreed to ensure that project cities consider establishing 
heating assistance programs for the poor with adequate annual government budget. Cost savings 
resulting from the efficiency improvement of the Project will be passed on the poor in the forms of 
heating bill discounts. These programs will be designed to alleviate the affordability problems in 
the project cities. Based on the projected share of urban consumers, their electricity consumption 
pattern, number of the poor living below the poverty line, the projected cost savings and the 
estimated tariff reduction, the share of the consumer surplus going to the poor is estimated at 
7.0%. 
 
6.  From a national perspective, the gains of CNY848 million (the gains of the Government) 
are mainly the environmental benefits and income taxes with the Project. There are some 
government  losses  from  capital  investment  and  operating  costs  (CNY60 million  and 
CNY122 million, respectively). The gain is further offset by the financial losses of CNY181 million 
(at 12% discount rate). A 2001 Asian Development Bank (ADB) publication indicates that the poor 
are  disproportionately  affected  by  environmental  degradation.3 The  poor  do  not  have  the 
information about and access to, or cannot afford more efficient (less-polluting) equipment and 
fuels. The gas distribution and heating supply networks are usually less well functioning or absent 
in the poorer sections of cities. The inadequate gas distribution and heating networks increase the 
exposure of the poor to daily doses of pollutants as well as the risk of accidents. Indoor air 
pollution puts, in particular, women and children at risk. Based on the discussions with the 
Executing Agency (EA), the local environmental protection agency, and the project preparatory 
technical  assistance  (PPTA)  consultants,  this  analysis  estimates  that  the  share  of  the 
Government net benefits (environmental benefits) going to the poor below the poverty line will be 
17%. 
 
7.  The direct employment effect of the Project during construction is an important benefit 
from the Project. The local currency portion of the Project is about 54% of the project cost. Out of 
the 54%, the non-equipment portion is substantial. Part of that will benefit the rural poor in the 
project area by direct employment.4 Since the poor are normally unskilled labors, they will be the 
beneficiaries of the Project as the current wages would be higher than their opportunity costs. 
Based on the projected labor employed in the Project through a special employment program for 
the poor, particularly in gas distribution and central heating supply subcomponents, 15% of the 
surplus for unskilled labor will go to the urban poor.
